summary:
As a nurse scientist and policy advisor I am driven to stimulate high quality patient centered (palliative) care in the dailly nursing practice. Focused on elderly care. In all of my work I strive to bridge the gap between  the field of practice, education and research.
Most of my projects are focused on empowering nurses to deliver high quality value based care. 

I work as a senior policy advisor at Zuyderland Medisch en Zorgconcern focussing on Palliative care projects, EU technology projects (Seventh Framework Programme, Horizons 2020), Academic Collaborative Center South Limburg.

Furthermore I work as Associate Professor at Maastricht University, faculty of Health, Medicine and Life Sciences, department Health Services Research.  Working in the Skill lab in Aging & Longterm Care Limburg for Elderly which is a collaboration between University Maastricht and Care foundations like Zuyderland Medisch en Zorgconcern to intergrate Science and practice. In this skill lab I am focussing on increasing quality of the Palliative care.

I am pricipal investigator of the 4 year research implementation project DEDICATED. With the goal to improve quality of Care for people with dementia in end of life.  Moreover I am projectleader of DEDICATED (www.dedicatedwerkwijze.nl), LISTEN (end of life communication as part of ACP), LINC (workplace Learning in Long Term Care, ACCENT (fist part) (autonomy supportive behaviour in elderly nursing care. 

Copromoter of 5 finished dissertations and currenty supervising 4 PhD students.

>80 peer reviewed publications, reviewer of Several journals like jAMDA, JACS, Journal of clinical nursing. Editor board member NVTPZ

Member of nursing leadership program ‘leadership Mentoring Nursing Research’.
Steering group member commission guidelines V&VN. Member Scientific advisory board Zuyderland.
Supervisory board V&VN.

I am Visiting Professor at the University of Alberta, Faculty of Nursing, Edmonton Canada.

profile_positions.description:
Thesis 'Awareness of Malnutrition in healthcare: The Dutch perspective'. 

 Thesis subject is the prevalence, prevention, treatment and policy indicators of malnutrition in Dutch Health Care organisations.


Summary Thesis (all 7 articles are published)
Malnutrition (i.e. undernutrition) is an important, under-recognised, and  undertreated  problem  in  healthcare.  Malnutrition  prevalence rates  in  all  healthcare  settings  are  high  (10-60%),  with  massive overall  cost  to  society.  Malnutrition  leads  to  prolonged  recovery, increases the need for high-dependency nursing care and the risk of  serious  complications,  and,  at  worst,  can  result  in  death  from  either  depletion  or  a  preventable  complication.  Increasing awareness  of  malnutrition  and  attention  to  adequate  nutritional care  may  positively  affect  both  the  prevalence  of  malnutrition  in healthcare and its consequences.
Pressure ulcers (PU) are another and also very topical healthcare problem. Their development depends on extrinsic and intrinsic risk factors.  Malnutrition  as  an  extrinsic  factor  seems  to  increase  the risk and impair the healing of PU. This thesis therefore addresses the healthcare problem of malnutrition and its relationship with PU.
The  thesis consists of two parts. The first part aims to describe the  definition  and  screening  of  malnutrition  and  investigate  whether increasing  awareness  (through  annual  audits  of  malnutrition prevalence and nutrition-related activities) improves the quality of
nutritional  care  in  hospitals,  nursing  homes  and  home  care (using  annualy 60.000 patient data from the International Prevalence Measurement of Care Problems (LPZ) https://www.lpz-um.eu/ )
The second part aims to increase evidence on the relationship between malnutrition  and  PU,  and  to  create  insight  into  the  extent  and benefits of implementing nutritional guidelines in PU care.

profile_positions.description:
Every person with dementia has an average of three caregivers. In the Netherlands there are more than 1 million professionals and care is fragmented. More than 70 percent of the nurses working in the palliative phase indicated not to feel competent enough. In homecare it is even more than 80 percent. 

A four-year project aimed at improving the quality of palliative care for people with dementia will receive 1 million Euro from ZonMw.
The project will officially start in September 2017. It is a cooperation between Zuyderland Zorgcentra (coordinator of the project), Academische Werkplaats Ouderenzorg, Zuyd University of Applied Sciences, Huis voor de Zorg, Vivantes, Envida, Hulp bij dementia, Vilans, V&VN, IKNL, CZ, Expertise Centrum Palliatieve Zorg MUMC+, Consortium Palliatieve Zorg Limburg en Brabant, and Propallia, Netwerk Palliatieve zorg Westelijke Mijnstreek and LUMC. 

Dr Judith Meijers is the projectleader.

profile_positions.description:
The Leadership Mentoring in Nursing Research program aims at building a new generation of future research leaders and strengthening nursing research capacity. The program is a two year leadership program for maximum twelve fellows. 

During the two year program the fellows work on their research project, follow courses based on their personal needs and attend workshops and meeting within the program.
